title: Kuina Was Murdered (Not an Accident)
description: This theory proposes that Kuina's death was not actually an accident from falling down stairs, but rather she was murdered. Some versions of this theory suggest various perpetrators, from her father Koushirou to the World Government. Fans find it implausible that a skilled swordsman like Kuina, who could defeat Zoro 2001 times, would die from such a mundane accident.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidencePoints: The timing of her death (the day after their promise) seems too convenient
It's unusual for a skilled fighter to die from falling down stairs
The death scene is never actually shown in the manga or anime
Koushirou's calm reaction to his daughter's death seems suspicious to some fans

title: Wado Ichimonji Killed Kuina (Cursed Sword)
description: This theory suggests that the Wado Ichimonji sword itself caused Kuina's death by draining her life force. Drawing parallels to Enma (another sword created by Shimotsuki Kouzaburou), which is known to extract excessive Armament Haki from its wielder, fans theorize that Wado similarly drained Kuina's energy the day after she wielded it. The theory proposes that the sword chose her before she was ready to handle its power, ultimately leading to her death.
author: Aaheli Pradhan
evidencePoints: Kuina died the day after using the Wado Ichimonji in their duel
Enma (also created by Kouzaburou) is known to drain excessive haki from users
The Shimotsuki family swords may have special properties that require mastery
Wano Arc revelations about cursed/demanding swords support this theory

title: Kuina is Still Alive (Tashigi Connection)
description: This popular theory suggests that Kuina didn't actually die but survived the fall with severe memory loss and became the Marine officer Tashigi. Supporters point to the striking physical resemblance between the two characters, their similar sword fighting styles, and Tashigi's strong beliefs about swords and honor. The theory proposes that Kuina either ran away or was in a coma, eventually recovering with amnesia.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidencePoints: Tashigi looks remarkably similar to what an adult Kuina might look like
Both are skilled female swordswomen
Tashigi shares Kuina's passion for swords and believes strongly in sword philosophy
Zoro's strong reaction to meeting Tashigi suggests recognition
Kuina's death scene was never actually shown
debunkingEvidence: Eiichiro Oda has confirmed that Kuina is actually dead, noting that Zoro attended her burial. However, this hasn't completely stopped fan speculation.

title: Kuina's Death Was Suicide (Cultural Euphemism)
description: Some fans theorize that 'falling down the stairs' is a euphemism for suicide in Japanese culture, suggesting Kuina took her own life due to her fears about being limited as a female swordsman. According to this theory, One Piece couldn't explicitly address suicide due to its younger target demographic, so Oda used coded language instead.
author: Various Reddit users
evidencePoints: Kuina expressed deep frustration about being limited as a girl
The timing (right after making the promise) could suggest despair
The manner of death seems deliberately vague
Some claim 'falling down stairs' is a known euphemism in Japanese
debunkingEvidence: Many fans dispute that 'falling down stairs' is actually a Japanese euphemism for suicide, calling this interpretation a Western misunderstanding. Additionally, Kuina's confident personality shown in the flashback doesn't align with this theory.

title: World Government Killed Kuina
description: This theory proposes that the World Government or one of the Gorosei discovered the connection between Shimotsuki Village and Wano Country after Kouzaburou's death. Upon finding Koushirou and Kuina connected to Wano, they killed Kuina when Koushirou wasn't present, either to prevent the spread of Wano's swordsmanship techniques or to eliminate potential threats from the Shimotsuki lineage.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidencePoints: The Shimotsuki family's connection to Wano was revealed in later arcs
The World Government has a history of eliminating threats
The timing and manner of death remain suspicious
This would explain Koushirou's composed reaction if he knew the truth but couldn't reveal it

title: Koushirou Killed His Own Daughter
description: A dark theory suggesting that Koushirou killed Kuina himself, either because he didn't want a female swordsman to surpass traditional boundaries, or to motivate Zoro to become even stronger through grief. This theory points to Koushirou's unusually calm demeanor after his daughter's death and his traditional views about women in combat as potential evidence.
author: Various forum users
evidencePoints: Koushirou held traditional views about women's limitations in combat
His unusually calm reaction to his daughter's death
He immediately gave away her prized sword to Zoro
Some fans see this as a way to forge the perfect swordsman through trauma
The death is never shown on screen
debunkingEvidence: There is no actual evidence supporting this theory, and it contradicts Koushirou's characterization as a caring father and mentor. Most fans consider this theory too dark and unlikely for One Piece's tone.
